awd_titl_txt: Wind-driven Variability in Heat Storage and the Meridional Overturning Circulation
awd_abstract_narration:
Observations and climate models show that winds are responsible for much of the seasonal to interannual variability in ocean heat content and the meridional overturning circulation (MOC). This study is focused on gaining a better understanding of how the ocean adjusts to variable winds, with particular focus on climatically important quantities such as ocean heat content and the MOC strength and pathways. A theoretical framework will be developed to better understand how these quantities depend on the controlling parameters, including mean stratification; region, structure, and frequency of wind variability; bottom topography; and mean state (including wind-driven gyres and a mean overturning circulation). The idealized approach adopted will allow for a general understanding of the controlling physics, including how they will vary in different oceans around the world, and in a future climate where the mean state and forcing variability might be different than at present. The results of this study will be  incorporated into graduate level classes and lectures at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute (WHOI)  Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Summer School, and participation will be sought from undergraduate students through the WHOI Summer Student Fellow Program. This will provide training in numerical methods, applied mathematics, climate, and data analysis. Results from this work will be made available through the peer-reviewed literature, national and international meetings, and web page content.
 
Despite its known importance for climate, there is currently no analytic theory for how transients in wind-forcing modify ocean heat storage and transport by the overturning circulation. This work will combine known features of the large-scale, low frequency ocean circulation, such as geostrophy, wave transients, and eddy fluxes, in a simple and compact way to represent climatically important integrated quantities such as ocean heat content and mass transports. The primary intellectual merit of the proposed work lies in developing a theoretical framework to connect regions of variable wind stress to remote ocean currents. This inevitably involves understanding how heat is stored and transported on both gyre- and global-scales in the ocean. The starting point is a linear theory based on isopycnal mass budgets in the interior subject to Sverdrup dynamics and Rossby and boundary wave transients. The predictions from the theory, and the importance of such nonlinear processes as outcropping, eddy fluxes, closed potential vorticity contours, and inertial western boundary currents, will be assessed with the use of idealized numerical models and published ocean state estimates from the ECCO (Estimating the Circulation and Climate of the Ocean) consortium. Diagnostics from these more complete models will also be used to guide revisions to the linear theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to gain a fundamental understanding of how variations in atmospheric winds influence the transport and storage of heat in the ocean. Winds vary on time scales of days to decades and from the equator to the pole. The ocean response depends on the spatial pattern and time-scale over which the winds are varying, as well as the strength and latitude of the variability. The approach used a combination of idealized computer models and mathematical theory. The theory provides a clear understanding of why the systems behave as they do and the computer models, which represent more complete physics, serve as a check on the fidelity of the mathematical solutions.

It was found that The ocean reponse depends strongly on the latitude and frequency of forcing. For typical winds, the ocean moves millions of cubic meters of water per second thousands of kilometers across the ocean basins. This will influence air-sea exchanges of heat and transports of freshwater, nutrients, carbon, and other oceanic tracers. The magnitude of these transports are similar to other well-known mechanisms of variability in the ocean and thus represent an important component of the earth system. The nature of the ocean response results in current anomalies thousands of kilometers away from the region of wind anomalies, sometimes even crossing into the opposite hemisphere.

This grant also supported work related to how wind- and buoyancy-forcing drive vertical transports in the ocean. Aside from being a basic element of the three dimensional ocean circulation, this is also important because it may bring waters into, or remove them from, contact with the atmosphere, thus impacting the exchange of heat, freshwater, carbon, and other tracers between the atmosphere and ocean.
